snp1.8:1.1: See [an5.169:3.1]() for this sense of _atthakusala_. | _Kusala_ in the sense of “one who is skilled”, an “expert” is found occasionally in the canon, especially in the Aṭṭhakavagga. It appears also in early Sanskrit, for example, for those who are “skilled” in recitation (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.8.1), or for those who only think that they are skilled (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.4.2.1, 4, and 13).
snp1.8:1.2: Reading the absolutive in an infinitive sense, per commentery: _abhisamecca viharitukāmena_.
snp1.8:4.3: Creatures “firm and frail” (_tasathāvare_) is a common Jain idiom (eg. Uttarādhyayana 5.8: _tasesu thāvaresu ya_; Sūyagaḍa 3.4.20: _je keī tasathāvarā_; Dasaveyāliya 4.1.42: _tasaṁ vā thāvaraṁ vā_; Ācāraṅgasūtra 9.1.14: _tasa-jīvā ya thāvarattāe_).
snp1.8:5.3: For “have become or will be” (_bhūtā va sambhavesī va_) I follow Norman and Bodhi in reading _sambhavesī_ as a future active participle. Compare such Sanskrit constructions as Rig Veda 1.66.8, _yamo ha jāto yamo janitvaṁ_ (“the twin that is born and the twin about to be born”) and Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.3.1.24, _bhūtaṁ caiva bhaviṣyacca jātaṁ ca janiṣyamāṇaṁ_ (“has become and will be, born and to be born”).
snp1.8:10.4: Note that _jātu_ here is not connected to _jāti_ “birth”. Rather, _na hi jātu_ is an idiom meaning “never”. Commentary: _ekaṁseneva_.
